36/*
37 * This macro defines the authentication state. If x is 1 authentication
38 * is required; otherwise it is optional.
39 */
40#define AUTH(x, y) ((x) ? (y) == AUTH_OK \
41 : (y) == AUTH_OK || (y) == AUTH_NONE)
42
43typedef enum
44auth_state {
45 AUTH_UNKNOWN = -1, /* Unknown */
46 AUTH_NONE, /* authentication not required */
47 AUTH_OK, /* authentication OK */
48 AUTH_ERROR, /* authentication error */
49 AUTH_CRYPTO /* crypto_NAK */
50} auth_code;
51
52/*
53 * Set up Kiss Code values
54 */
55
56typedef enum
57kiss_codes {
58 NOKISS, /* No Kiss Code */
59 RATEKISS, /* Rate limit Kiss Code */
60 DENYKISS, /* Deny Kiss */
61 RSTRKISS, /* Restricted Kiss */
62 XKISS /* Experimental Kiss */
63} kiss_code;
64
65typedef enum
66nak_error_codes {
67 NONAK, /* No NAK seen */
68 INVALIDNAK, /* NAK cannot be used */
69 VALIDNAK /* NAK is valid */
70} nak_code;
71
72/*
73 * traffic shaping parameters
74 */
75#define NTP_IBURST 6 /* packets in iburst */
76#define RESP_DELAY 1 /* refclock burst delay (s) */
77
78/*
79 * pool soliciting restriction duration (s)
80 */
81#define POOL_SOLICIT_WINDOW 8

83/*
84 * peer_select groups statistics for a peer used by clock_select() and
85 * clock_cluster().
86 */
87typedef struct peer_select_tag {
88 struct peer * peer;
89 double synch; /* sync distance */
90 double error; /* jitter */
91 double seljit; /* selection jitter */
92} peer_select;

94/*
95 * System variables are declared here. Unless specified otherwise, all
96 * times are in seconds.
97 */
98u_char sys_leap; /* system leap indicator, use set_sys_leap() to change this */
99u_char xmt_leap; /* leap indicator sent in client requests, set up by set_sys_leap() */
100u_char sys_stratum; /* system stratum */
101s_char sys_precision; /* local clock precision (log2 s) */
102double sys_rootdelay; /* roundtrip delay to primary source */
103double sys_rootdisp; /* dispersion to primary source */
104u_int32 sys_refid; /* reference id (network byte order) */
105l_fp sys_reftime; /* last update time */
106struct peer *sys_peer; /* current peer */
107
108#ifdef LEAP_SMEAR
109struct leap_smear_info leap_smear;
110#endif
111int leap_sec_in_progress;
112
113/*
114 * Rate controls. Leaky buckets are used to throttle the packet
115 * transmission rates in order to protect busy servers such as at NIST
116 * and USNO. There is a counter for each association and another for KoD
117 * packets. The association counter decrements each second, but not
118 * below zero. Each time a packet is sent the counter is incremented by
119 * a configurable value representing the average interval between
120 * packets. A packet is delayed as long as the counter is greater than
121 * zero. Note this does not affect the time value computations.
122 */
123/*
124 * Nonspecified system state variables
125 */
126int sys_bclient; /* broadcast client enable */
127double sys_bdelay; /* broadcast client default delay */
128int sys_authenticate; /* requre authentication for config */
129l_fp sys_authdelay; /* authentication delay */
130double sys_offset; /* current local clock offset */
131double sys_mindisp = MINDISPERSE; /* minimum distance (s) */
132double sys_maxdist = MAXDISTANCE; /* selection threshold */
133double sys_jitter; /* system jitter */
134u_long sys_epoch; /* last clock update time */
135static double sys_clockhop; /* clockhop threshold */
136static int leap_vote_ins; /* leap consensus for insert */
137static int leap_vote_del; /* leap consensus for delete */
138keyid_t sys_private; /* private value for session seed */
139int sys_manycastserver; /* respond to manycast client pkts */
140int ntp_mode7; /* respond to ntpdc (mode7) */
141int peer_ntpdate; /* active peers in ntpdate mode */
142int sys_survivors; /* truest of the truechimers */
143char *sys_ident = NULL; /* identity scheme */
144
145/*
146 * TOS and multicast mapping stuff
147 */
148int sys_floor = 0; /* cluster stratum floor */
149u_char sys_bcpollbstep = 0; /* Broadcast Poll backstep gate */
150int sys_ceiling = STRATUM_UNSPEC - 1; /* cluster stratum ceiling */
151int sys_minsane = 1; /* minimum candidates */
152int sys_minclock = NTP_MINCLOCK; /* minimum candidates */
153int sys_maxclock = NTP_MAXCLOCK; /* maximum candidates */
154int sys_cohort = 0; /* cohort switch */
155int sys_orphan = STRATUM_UNSPEC + 1; /* orphan stratum */
156int sys_orphwait = NTP_ORPHWAIT; /* orphan wait */
157int sys_beacon = BEACON; /* manycast beacon interval */
158u_int sys_ttlmax; /* max ttl mapping vector index */
159u_char sys_ttl[MAX_TTL]; /* ttl mapping vector */
160
161/*
162 * Statistics counters - first the good, then the bad
163 */
164u_long sys_stattime; /* elapsed time */
165u_long sys_received; /* packets received */
166u_long sys_processed; /* packets for this host */
167u_long sys_newversion; /* current version */
168u_long sys_oldversion; /* old version */
169u_long sys_restricted; /* access denied */
170u_long sys_badlength; /* bad length or format */
171u_long sys_badauth; /* bad authentication */
172u_long sys_declined; /* declined */
173u_long sys_limitrejected; /* rate exceeded */
174u_long sys_kodsent; /* KoD sent */
175
176/*
177 * Mechanism knobs: how soon do we peer_clear() or unpeer()?
178 *
179 * The default way is "on-receipt". If this was a packet from a
180 * well-behaved source, on-receipt will offer the fastest recovery.
181 * If this was from a DoS attack, the default way makes it easier
182 * for a bad-guy to DoS us. So look and see what bites you harder
183 * and choose according to your environment.
184 */
185int peer_clear_digest_early = 1; /* bad digest (TEST5) and Autokey */
186int unpeer_crypto_early = 1; /* bad crypto (TEST9) */
187int unpeer_crypto_nak_early = 1; /* crypto_NAK (TEST5) */
188int unpeer_digest_early = 1; /* bad digest (TEST5) */
189
190int dynamic_interleave = DYNAMIC_INTERLEAVE; /* Bug 2978 mitigation */
191
192int kiss_code_check(u_char hisleap, u_char hisstratum, u_char hismode, u_int32 refid);
193nak_code valid_NAK (struct peer *peer, struct recvbuf *rbufp, u_char hismode);
194static double root_distance (struct peer *);
195static void clock_combine (peer_select *, int, int);
196static void peer_xmit (struct peer *);
197static void fast_xmit (struct recvbuf *, int, keyid_t, int);
198static void pool_xmit (struct peer *);
199static void clock_update (struct peer *);
200static void measure_precision(void);
201static double measure_tick_fuzz(void);
202static int local_refid (struct peer *);
203static int peer_unfit (struct peer *);
204#ifdef AUTOKEY
205static int group_test (char *, char *);
206#endif /* AUTOKEY */
207#ifdef WORKER
208void pool_name_resolved (int, int, void *, const char *,
209 const char *, const struct addrinfo *,
210 const struct addrinfo *);
211#endif /* WORKER */

213const char * amtoa (int am);

215
216void
217set_sys_leap(
218 u_char new_sys_leap
219 )
220{
221 sys_leap = new_sys_leap;
222 xmt_leap = sys_leap;
223
224 /*
225 * Under certain conditions we send faked leap bits to clients, so
226 * eventually change xmt_leap below, but never change LEAP_NOTINSYNC.
227 */
228 if (xmt_leap != LEAP_NOTINSYNC) {
229 if (leap_sec_in_progress) {
230 /* always send "not sync" */
231 xmt_leap = LEAP_NOTINSYNC;
232 }
233#ifdef LEAP_SMEAR
234 else {
235 /*
236 * If leap smear is enabled in general we must
237 * never send a leap second warning to clients,
238 * so make sure we only send "in sync".
239 */
240 if (leap_smear.enabled)
241 xmt_leap = LEAP_NOWARNING;
242 }
243#endif /* LEAP_SMEAR */
244 }
245}
246
247
248/*
249 * Kiss Code check
250 */
251int
252kiss_code_check(
253 u_char hisleap,
254 u_char hisstratum,
255 u_char hismode,
256 u_int32 refid
257 )
258{
259
260 if ( hismode == MODE_SERVER
261 && hisleap == LEAP_NOTINSYNC
262 && hisstratum == STRATUM_UNSPEC) {
263 if(memcmp(&refid,"RATE", 4) == 0) {
264 return (RATEKISS);
265 } else if(memcmp(&refid,"DENY", 4) == 0) {
266 return (DENYKISS);
267 } else if(memcmp(&refid,"RSTR", 4) == 0) {
268 return (RSTRKISS);
269 } else if(memcmp(&refid,"X", 1) == 0) {
270 return (XKISS);
271 }
272 }
273 return (NOKISS);
274}
275
276
277/*
278 * Check that NAK is valid
279 */
280nak_code
281valid_NAK(
282 struct peer *peer,
283 struct recvbuf *rbufp,
284 u_char hismode
285 )
286{
287 int base_packet_length = MIN_V4_PKT_LEN;
288 int remainder_size;
289 struct pkt * rpkt;
290 int keyid;
291 l_fp p_org; /* origin timestamp */
292 const l_fp * myorg; /* selected peer origin */
293
294 /*
295 * Check to see if there is something beyond the basic packet
296 */
297 if (rbufp->recv_length == base_packet_length) {
298 return NONAK;
299 }
300
301 remainder_size = rbufp->recv_length - base_packet_length;
302 /*
303 * Is this a potential NAK?
304 */
305 if (remainder_size != 4) {
306 return NONAK;
307 }
308
309 /*
310 * Only server responses can contain NAK's
311 */
312
313 if (hismode != MODE_SERVER &&
314 hismode != MODE_ACTIVE &&
315 hismode != MODE_PASSIVE
316 ) {
317 return INVALIDNAK;
318 }
319
320 /*
321 * Make sure that the extra field in the packet is all zeros
322 */
323 rpkt = &rbufp->recv_pkt;
324 keyid = ntohl(((u_int32 *)rpkt)[base_packet_length / 4]);
325 if (keyid != 0) {
326 return INVALIDNAK;
327 }
328
329 /*
330 * During the first few packets of the autokey dance there will
331 * not (yet) be a keyid, but in this case FLAG_SKEY is set.
332 * So the NAK is invalid if either there's no peer, or
333 * if the keyid is 0 and FLAG_SKEY is not set.
334 */
335 if (!peer || (!peer->keyid && !(peer->flags & FLAG_SKEY))) {
336 return INVALIDNAK;
337 }
338
339 /*
340 * The ORIGIN must match, or this cannot be a valid NAK, either.
341 */
342 NTOHL_FP(&rpkt->org, &p_org);
343 if (peer->flip > 0)
344 myorg = &peer->borg;
345 else
346 myorg = &peer->aorg;
347
348 if (L_ISZERO(&p_org) ||
349 L_ISZERO( myorg) ||
350 !L_ISEQU(&p_org, myorg)) {
351 return INVALIDNAK;
352 }
353
354 /* If we ever passed all that checks, we should be safe. Well,
355 * as safe as we can ever be with an unauthenticated crypto-nak.
356 */
357 return VALIDNAK;
358}
359
360
361/*
362 * transmit - transmit procedure called by poll timeout
363 */
364void
365transmit(
366 struct peer *peer /* peer structure pointer */
367 )
368{
369 u_char hpoll;
370
371 /*
372 * The polling state machine. There are two kinds of machines,
373 * those that never expect a reply (broadcast and manycast
374 * server modes) and those that do (all other modes). The dance
375 * is intricate...
376 */
377 hpoll = peer->hpoll;
378
379 /*
380 * If we haven't received anything (even if unsync) since last
381 * send, reset ppoll.
382 */
383 if (peer->outdate > peer->timelastrec && !peer->reach)
384 peer->ppoll = peer->maxpoll;
385
386 /*
387 * In broadcast mode the poll interval is never changed from
388 * minpoll.
389 */
390 if (peer->cast_flags & (MDF_BCAST | MDF_MCAST)) {
391 peer->outdate = current_time;
392 if (sys_leap != LEAP_NOTINSYNC)
393 peer_xmit(peer);
394 poll_update(peer, hpoll);
395 return;
396 }
397
398 /*
399 * In manycast mode we start with unity ttl. The ttl is
400 * increased by one for each poll until either sys_maxclock
401 * servers have been found or the maximum ttl is reached. When
402 * sys_maxclock servers are found we stop polling until one or
403 * more servers have timed out or until less than sys_minclock
404 * associations turn up. In this case additional better servers
405 * are dragged in and preempt the existing ones. Once every
406 * sys_beacon seconds we are to transmit unconditionally, but
407 * this code is not quite right -- peer->unreach counts polls
408 * and is being compared with sys_beacon, so the beacons happen
409 * every sys_beacon polls.
410 */
411 if (peer->cast_flags & MDF_ACAST) {
412 peer->outdate = current_time;
413 if (peer->unreach > sys_beacon) {
414 peer->unreach = 0;
415 peer->ttl = 0;
416 peer_xmit(peer);
417 } else if ( sys_survivors < sys_minclock
418 || peer_associations < sys_maxclock) {
419 if (peer->ttl < sys_ttlmax)
420 peer->ttl++;
421 peer_xmit(peer);
422 }
423 peer->unreach++;
424 poll_update(peer, hpoll);
425 return;
426 }
427
428 /*
429 * Pool associations transmit unicast solicitations when there
430 * are less than a hard limit of 2 * sys_maxclock associations,
431 * and either less than sys_minclock survivors or less than
432 * sys_maxclock associations. The hard limit prevents unbounded
433 * growth in associations if the system clock or network quality
434 * result in survivor count dipping below sys_minclock often.
435 * This was observed testing with pool, where sys_maxclock == 12
436 * resulted in 60 associations without the hard limit. A
437 * similar hard limit on manycastclient ephemeral associations
438 * may be appropriate.
439 */
440 if (peer->cast_flags & MDF_POOL) {
441 peer->outdate = current_time;
442 if ( (peer_associations <= 2 * sys_maxclock)
443 && ( peer_associations < sys_maxclock
444 || sys_survivors < sys_minclock))
445 pool_xmit(peer);
446 poll_update(peer, hpoll);
447 return;
448 }
449
450 /*
451 * In unicast modes the dance is much more intricate. It is
452 * designed to back off whenever possible to minimize network
453 * traffic.
454 */
455 if (peer->burst == 0) {
456 u_char oreach;
457
458 /*
459 * Update the reachability status. If not heard for
460 * three consecutive polls, stuff infinity in the clock
461 * filter.
462 */
463 oreach = peer->reach;
464 peer->outdate = current_time;
465 peer->unreach++;
466 peer->reach <<= 1;
467 if (!peer->reach) {
468
469 /*
470 * Here the peer is unreachable. If it was
471 * previously reachable raise a trap. Send a
472 * burst if enabled.
473 */
474 clock_filter(peer, 0., 0., MAXDISPERSE);
475 if (oreach) {
476 peer_unfit(peer);
477 report_event(PEVNT_UNREACH, peer, NULL);
478 }
479 if ( (peer->flags & FLAG_IBURST)
480 && peer->retry == 0)
481 peer->retry = NTP_RETRY;
482 } else {
483
484 /*
485 * Here the peer is reachable. Send a burst if
486 * enabled and the peer is fit. Reset unreach
487 * for persistent and ephemeral associations.
488 * Unreach is also reset for survivors in
489 * clock_select().
490 */
491 hpoll = sys_poll;
492 if (!(peer->flags & FLAG_PREEMPT))
493 peer->unreach = 0;
494 if ( (peer->flags & FLAG_BURST)
495 && peer->retry == 0
496 && !peer_unfit(peer))
497 peer->retry = NTP_RETRY;
498 }
499
500 /*
501 * Watch for timeout. If ephemeral, toss the rascal;
502 * otherwise, bump the poll interval. Note the
503 * poll_update() routine will clamp it to maxpoll.
504 * If preemptible and we have more peers than maxclock,
505 * and this peer has the minimum score of preemptibles,
506 * demobilize.
507 */
508 if (peer->unreach >= NTP_UNREACH) {
509 hpoll++;
510 /* ephemeral: no FLAG_CONFIG nor FLAG_PREEMPT */
511 if (!(peer->flags & (FLAG_CONFIG | FLAG_PREEMPT))) {
512 report_event(PEVNT_RESTART, peer, "timeout");
513 peer_clear(peer, "TIME");
514 unpeer(peer);
515 return;
516 }
517 if ( (peer->flags & FLAG_PREEMPT)
518 && (peer_associations > sys_maxclock)
519 && score_all(peer)) {
520 report_event(PEVNT_RESTART, peer, "timeout");
521 peer_clear(peer, "TIME");
522 unpeer(peer);
523 return;
524 }
525 }
526 } else {
527 peer->burst--;
528 if (peer->burst == 0) {
529
530 /*
531 * If ntpdate mode and the clock has not been
532 * set and all peers have completed the burst,
533 * we declare a successful failure.
534 */
535 if (mode_ntpdate) {
536 peer_ntpdate--;
537 if (peer_ntpdate == 0) {
538 msyslog(LOG_NOTICE,
539 "ntpd: no servers found");
540 if (!msyslog_term)
541 printf(
542 "ntpd: no servers found\n");
543 exit (0);
544 }
545 }
546 }
547 }
548 if (peer->retry > 0)
549 peer->retry--;
550
551 /*
552 * Do not transmit if in broadcast client mode.
553 */
554 if (peer->hmode != MODE_BCLIENT)
555 peer_xmit(peer);
556 poll_update(peer, hpoll);
557
558 return;
559}
560
561
562const char *
563amtoa(
564 int am
565 )
566{
567 char *bp;
568
569 switch(am) {
570 case AM_ERR: return "AM_ERR";
571 case AM_NOMATCH: return "AM_NOMATCH";
572 case AM_PROCPKT: return "AM_PROCPKT";
573 case AM_BCST: return "AM_BCST";
574 case AM_FXMIT: return "AM_FXMIT";
575 case AM_MANYCAST: return "AM_MANYCAST";
576 case AM_NEWPASS: return "AM_NEWPASS";
577 case AM_NEWBCL: return "AM_NEWBCL";
578 case AM_POSSBCL: return "AM_POSSBCL";
579 default:
580 LIB_GETBUF(bp);
581 snprintf(bp, LIB_BUFLENGTH, "AM_#%d", am);
582 return bp;
583 }
584}
585
586
587/*
588 * receive - receive procedure called for each packet received
589 */
590void
591receive(
592 struct recvbuf *rbufp
593 )
594{
595 register struct peer *peer; /* peer structure pointer */
596 register struct pkt *pkt; /* receive packet pointer */
597 u_char hisversion; /* packet version */
598 u_char hisleap; /* packet leap indicator */
599 u_char hismode; /* packet mode */
600 u_char hisstratum; /* packet stratum */
601 r4addr r4a; /* address restrictions */
602 u_short restrict_mask; /* restrict bits */
603 const char *hm_str; /* hismode string */
604 const char *am_str; /* association match string */
605 int kissCode = NOKISS; /* Kiss Code */
606 int has_mac; /* length of MAC field */
607 int authlen; /* offset of MAC field */
608 auth_code is_authentic = AUTH_UNKNOWN; /* Was AUTH_NONE */
609 nak_code crypto_nak_test; /* result of crypto-NAK check */
610 int retcode = AM_NOMATCH; /* match code */
611 keyid_t skeyid = 0; /* key IDs */
612 u_int32 opcode = 0; /* extension field opcode */
613 sockaddr_u *dstadr_sin; /* active runway */
614 struct peer *peer2; /* aux peer structure pointer */
615 endpt *match_ep; /* newpeer() local address */
616 l_fp p_org; /* origin timestamp */
617 l_fp p_rec; /* receive timestamp */
618 l_fp p_xmt; /* transmit timestamp */
619#ifdef AUTOKEY
620 char hostname[NTP_MAXSTRLEN + 1];
621 char *groupname = NULL;
622 struct autokey *ap; /* autokey structure pointer */
623 int rval; /* cookie snatcher */
624 keyid_t pkeyid = 0, tkeyid = 0; /* key IDs */
625#endif /* AUTOKEY */
626#ifdef HAVE_NTP_SIGND
627 static unsigned char zero_key[16];
628#endif /* HAVE_NTP_SIGND */
629
630 /*
631 * Note that there are many places we do not call record_raw_stats().
632 *
633 * We only want to call it *after* we've sent a response, or perhaps
634 * when we've decided to drop a packet.
635 */
636
637 /*
638 * Monitor the packet and get restrictions. Note that the packet
639 * length for control and private mode packets must be checked
640 * by the service routines. Some restrictions have to be handled
641 * later in order to generate a kiss-o'-death packet.
642 */
643 /*
644 * Bogus port check is before anything, since it probably
645 * reveals a clogging attack.
646 */
647 sys_received++;
648 if (0 == SRCPORT(&rbufp->recv_srcadr)) {
649 sys_badlength++;
650 return; /* bogus port */
651 }
652 restrictions(&rbufp->recv_srcadr, &r4a);
653 restrict_mask = r4a.rflags;
654
655 pkt = &rbufp->recv_pkt;
656 hisversion = PKT_VERSION(pkt->li_vn_mode);
657 hisleap = PKT_LEAP(pkt->li_vn_mode);
658 hismode = (int)PKT_MODE(pkt->li_vn_mode);
659 hisstratum = PKT_TO_STRATUM(pkt->stratum);
660 DPRINTF(1, ("receive: at %ld %s<-%s ippeerlimit %d mode %d iflags %s restrict %s org %#010x.%08x xmt %#010x.%08x\n",
661 current_time, stoa(&rbufp->dstadr->sin),
662 stoa(&rbufp->recv_srcadr), r4a.ippeerlimit, hismode,
663 build_iflags(rbufp->dstadr->flags),
664 build_rflags(restrict_mask),
665 ntohl(pkt->org.l_ui), ntohl(pkt->org.l_uf),
666 ntohl(pkt->xmt.l_ui), ntohl(pkt->xmt.l_uf)));
667
668 /* See basic mode and broadcast checks, below */
669 INSIST(0 != hisstratum);
670
671 if (restrict_mask & RES_IGNORE) {
672 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: drop: RES_IGNORE\n"));
673 sys_restricted++;
674 return; /* ignore everything */
675 }
676 if (hismode == MODE_PRIVATE) {
677 if (!ntp_mode7 || (restrict_mask & RES_NOQUERY)) {
678 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: drop: RES_NOQUERY\n"));
679 sys_restricted++;
680 return; /* no query private */
681 }
682 process_private(rbufp, ((restrict_mask &
683 RES_NOMODIFY) == 0));
684 return;
685 }
686 if (hismode == MODE_CONTROL) {
687 if (restrict_mask & RES_NOQUERY) {
688 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: drop: RES_NOQUERY\n"));
689 sys_restricted++;
690 return; /* no query control */
691 }
692 process_control(rbufp, restrict_mask);
693 return;
694 }
695 if (restrict_mask & RES_DONTSERVE) {
696 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: drop: RES_DONTSERVE\n"));
697 sys_restricted++;
698 return; /* no time serve */
699 }
700
701 /*
702 * This is for testing. If restricted drop ten percent of
703 * surviving packets.
704 */
705 if (restrict_mask & RES_FLAKE) {
706 if ((double)ntp_random() / 0x7fffffff < .1) {
707 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: drop: RES_FLAKE\n"));
708 sys_restricted++;
709 return; /* no flakeway */
710 }
711 }
712
713 /*
714 ** Format Layer Checks
715 **
716 ** Validate the packet format. The packet size, packet header,
717 ** and any extension field lengths are checked. We identify
718 ** the beginning of the MAC, to identify the upper limit of
719 ** of the hash computation.
720 **
721 ** In case of a format layer check violation, the packet is
722 ** discarded with no further processing.
723 */
724
725 /*
726 * Version check must be after the query packets, since they
727 * intentionally use an early version.
728 */
729 if (hisversion == NTP_VERSION) {
730 sys_newversion++; /* new version */
731 } else if ( !(restrict_mask & RES_VERSION)
732 && hisversion >= NTP_OLDVERSION) {
733 sys_oldversion++; /* previous version */
734 } else {
735 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: drop: RES_VERSION\n"));
736 sys_badlength++;
737 return; /* old version */
738 }
739
740 /*
741 * Figure out his mode and validate the packet. This has some
742 * legacy raunch that probably should be removed. In very early
743 * NTP versions mode 0 was equivalent to what later versions
744 * would interpret as client mode.
745 */
746 if (hismode == MODE_UNSPEC) {
747 if (hisversion == NTP_OLDVERSION) {
748 hismode = MODE_CLIENT;
749 } else {
750 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: drop: MODE_UNSPEC\n"));
751 sys_badlength++;
752 return; /* invalid mode */
753 }
754 }
755
756 /*
757 * Parse the extension field if present. We figure out whether
758 * an extension field is present by measuring the MAC size. If
759 * the number of words following the packet header is 0, no MAC
760 * is present and the packet is not authenticated. If 1, the
761 * packet is a crypto-NAK; if 3, the packet is authenticated
762 * with DES; if 5, the packet is authenticated with MD5; if 6,
763 * the packet is authenticated with SHA. If 2 or * 4, the packet
764 * is a runt and discarded forthwith. If greater than 6, an
765 * extension field is present, so we subtract the length of the
766 * field and go around again.
767 *
768 * Note the above description is lame. We should/could also check
769 * the two bytes that make up the EF type and subtype, and then
770 * check the two bytes that tell us the EF length. A legacy MAC
771 * has a 4 byte keyID, and for conforming symmetric keys its value
772 * must be <= 64k, meaning the top two bytes will always be zero.
773 * Since the EF Type of 0 is reserved/unused, there's no way a
774 * conforming legacy MAC could ever be misinterpreted as an EF.
775 *
776 * There is more, but this isn't the place to document it.
777 */
778
779 authlen = LEN_PKT_NOMAC;
780 has_mac = rbufp->recv_length - authlen;
781 while (has_mac > 0) {
782 u_int32 len;
783#ifdef AUTOKEY
784 u_int32 hostlen;
785 struct exten *ep;
786#endif /*AUTOKEY */
787
788 if (has_mac % 4 != 0 || has_mac < (int)MIN_MAC_LEN) {
789 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: drop: bad post-packet length\n"));
790 sys_badlength++;
791 return; /* bad length */
792 }
793 /*
794 * This next test is clearly wrong - it needlessly
795 * prohibits short EFs (which don't yet exist)
796 */
797 if (has_mac <= (int)MAX_MAC_LEN) {
798 skeyid = ntohl(((u_int32 *)pkt)[authlen / 4]);
799 break;
800
801 } else {
802 opcode = ntohl(((u_int32 *)pkt)[authlen / 4]);
803 len = opcode & 0xffff;
804 if ( len % 4 != 0
805 || len < 4
806 || (int)len + authlen > rbufp->recv_length) {
807 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: drop: bad EF length\n"));
808 sys_badlength++;
809 return; /* bad length */
810 }
811#ifdef AUTOKEY
812 /*
813 * Extract calling group name for later. If
814 * sys_groupname is non-NULL, there must be
815 * a group name provided to elicit a response.
816 */
817 if ( (opcode & 0x3fff0000) == CRYPTO_ASSOC
818 && sys_groupname != NULL) {
819 ep = (struct exten *)&((u_int32 *)pkt)[authlen / 4];
820 hostlen = ntohl(ep->vallen);
821 if ( hostlen >= sizeof(hostname)
822 || hostlen > len -
823 offsetof(struct exten, pkt)) {
824 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: drop: bad autokey hostname length\n"));
825 sys_badlength++;
826 return; /* bad length */
827 }
828 memcpy(hostname, &ep->pkt, hostlen);
829 hostname[hostlen] = '\0';
830 groupname = strchr(hostname, '@');
831 if (groupname == NULL) {
832 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: drop: empty autokey groupname\n"));
833 sys_declined++;
834 return;
835 }
836 groupname++;
837 }
838#endif /* AUTOKEY */
839 authlen += len;
840 has_mac -= len;
841 }
842 }
843
844 /*
845 * If has_mac is < 0 we had a malformed packet.
846 */
847 if (has_mac < 0) {
848 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: drop: post-packet under-read\n"));
849 sys_badlength++;
850 return; /* bad length */
851 }
852
853 /*
854 ** Packet Data Verification Layer
855 **
856 ** This layer verifies the packet data content. If
857 ** authentication is required, a MAC must be present.
858 ** If a MAC is present, it must validate.
859 ** Crypto-NAK? Look - a shiny thing!
860 **
861 ** If authentication fails, we're done.
862 */
863
864 /*
865 * If authentication is explicitly required, a MAC must be present.
866 */
867 if (restrict_mask & RES_DONTTRUST && has_mac == 0) {
868 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: drop: RES_DONTTRUST\n"));
869 sys_restricted++;
870 return; /* access denied */
871 }
872
873 /*
874 * Update the MRU list and finger the cloggers. It can be a
875 * little expensive, so turn it off for production use.
876 * RES_LIMITED and RES_KOD will be cleared in the returned
877 * restrict_mask unless one or both actions are warranted.
878 */
879 restrict_mask = ntp_monitor(rbufp, restrict_mask);
880 if (restrict_mask & RES_LIMITED) {
881 sys_limitrejected++;
882 if ( !(restrict_mask & RES_KOD)
883 || MODE_BROADCAST == hismode
884 || MODE_SERVER == hismode) {
885 if (MODE_SERVER == hismode) {
886 DPRINTF(1, ("Possibly self-induced rate limiting of MODE_SERVER from %s\n",
887 stoa(&rbufp->recv_srcadr)));
888 } else {
889 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: drop: RES_KOD\n"));
890 }
891 return; /* rate exceeded */
892 }
893 if (hismode == MODE_CLIENT)
894 fast_xmit(rbufp, MODE_SERVER, skeyid,
895 restrict_mask);
896 else
897 fast_xmit(rbufp, MODE_ACTIVE, skeyid,
898 restrict_mask);
899 return; /* rate exceeded */
900 }
901 restrict_mask &= ~RES_KOD;
902
903 /*
904 * We have tossed out as many buggy packets as possible early in
905 * the game to reduce the exposure to a clogging attack. Now we
906 * have to burn some cycles to find the association and
907 * authenticate the packet if required. Note that we burn only
908 * digest cycles, again to reduce exposure. There may be no
909 * matching association and that's okay.
910 *
911 * More on the autokey mambo. Normally the local interface is
912 * found when the association was mobilized with respect to a
913 * designated remote address. We assume packets arriving from
914 * the remote address arrive via this interface and the local
915 * address used to construct the autokey is the unicast address
916 * of the interface. However, if the sender is a broadcaster,
917 * the interface broadcast address is used instead.
918 * Notwithstanding this technobabble, if the sender is a
919 * multicaster, the broadcast address is null, so we use the
920 * unicast address anyway. Don't ask.
921 */
922
923 peer = findpeer(rbufp, hismode, &retcode);
924 dstadr_sin = &rbufp->dstadr->sin;
925 NTOHL_FP(&pkt->org, &p_org);
926 NTOHL_FP(&pkt->rec, &p_rec);
927 NTOHL_FP(&pkt->xmt, &p_xmt);
928 hm_str = modetoa(hismode);
929 am_str = amtoa(retcode);
930
931 /*
932 * Authentication is conditioned by three switches:
933 *
934 * NOPEER (RES_NOPEER) do not mobilize an association unless
935 * authenticated
936 * NOTRUST (RES_DONTTRUST) do not allow access unless
937 * authenticated (implies NOPEER)
938 * enable (sys_authenticate) master NOPEER switch, by default
939 * on
940 *
941 * The NOPEER and NOTRUST can be specified on a per-client basis
942 * using the restrict command. The enable switch if on implies
943 * NOPEER for all clients. There are four outcomes:
944 *
945 * NONE The packet has no MAC.
946 * OK the packet has a MAC and authentication succeeds
947 * ERROR the packet has a MAC and authentication fails
948 * CRYPTO crypto-NAK. The MAC has four octets only.
949 *
950 * Note: The AUTH(x, y) macro is used to filter outcomes. If x
951 * is zero, acceptable outcomes of y are NONE and OK. If x is
952 * one, the only acceptable outcome of y is OK.
953 */
954 crypto_nak_test = valid_NAK(peer, rbufp, hismode);
955
956 /*
957 * Drop any invalid crypto-NAKs
958 */
959 if (crypto_nak_test == INVALIDNAK) {
960 report_event(PEVNT_AUTH, peer, "Invalid_NAK");
961 if (0 != peer) {
962 peer->badNAK++;
963 }
964 msyslog(LOG_ERR, "Invalid-NAK error at %ld %s<-%s",
965 current_time, stoa(dstadr_sin), stoa(&rbufp->recv_srcadr));
966 return;
967 }
968
969 if (has_mac == 0) {
970 restrict_mask &= ~RES_MSSNTP;
971 is_authentic = AUTH_NONE; /* not required */
972 DPRINTF(1, ("receive: at %ld %s<-%s mode %d/%s:%s len %d org %#010x.%08x xmt %#010x.%08x NOMAC\n",
973 current_time, stoa(dstadr_sin),
974 stoa(&rbufp->recv_srcadr), hismode, hm_str, am_str,
975 authlen,
976 ntohl(pkt->org.l_ui), ntohl(pkt->org.l_uf),
977 ntohl(pkt->xmt.l_ui), ntohl(pkt->xmt.l_uf)));
978 } else if (crypto_nak_test == VALIDNAK) {
979 restrict_mask &= ~RES_MSSNTP;
980 is_authentic = AUTH_CRYPTO; /* crypto-NAK */
981 DPRINTF(1, ("receive: at %ld %s<-%s mode %d/%s:%s keyid %08x len %d auth %d org %#010x.%08x xmt %#010x.%08x CRYPTONAK\n",
982 current_time, stoa(dstadr_sin),
983 stoa(&rbufp->recv_srcadr), hismode, hm_str, am_str,
984 skeyid, authlen + has_mac, is_authentic,
985 ntohl(pkt->org.l_ui), ntohl(pkt->org.l_uf),
986 ntohl(pkt->xmt.l_ui), ntohl(pkt->xmt.l_uf)));
987
988#ifdef HAVE_NTP_SIGND
989 /*
990 * If the signature is 20 bytes long, the last 16 of
991 * which are zero, then this is a Microsoft client
992 * wanting AD-style authentication of the server's
993 * reply.
994 *
995 * This is described in Microsoft's WSPP docs, in MS-SNTP:
996 * http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc212930.aspx
997 */
998 } else if ( has_mac == MAX_MD5_LEN
999 && (restrict_mask & RES_MSSNTP)
1000 && (retcode == AM_FXMIT || retcode == AM_NEWPASS)
1001 && (memcmp(zero_key, (char *)pkt + authlen + 4,
1002 MAX_MD5_LEN - 4) == 0)) {
1003 is_authentic = AUTH_NONE;
1004 DPRINTF(1, ("receive: at %ld %s<-%s mode %d/%s:%s len %d org %#010x.%08x xmt %#010x.%08x SIGND\n",
1005 current_time, stoa(dstadr_sin),
1006 stoa(&rbufp->recv_srcadr), hismode, hm_str, am_str,
1007 authlen,
1008 ntohl(pkt->org.l_ui), ntohl(pkt->org.l_uf),
1009 ntohl(pkt->xmt.l_ui), ntohl(pkt->xmt.l_uf)));
1010#endif /* HAVE_NTP_SIGND */
1011
1012 } else {
1013 /*
1014 * has_mac is not 0
1015 * Not a VALID_NAK
1016 * Not an MS-SNTP SIGND packet
1017 *
1018 * So there is a MAC here.
1019 */
1020
1021 restrict_mask &= ~RES_MSSNTP;
1022#ifdef AUTOKEY
1023 /*
1024 * For autokey modes, generate the session key
1025 * and install in the key cache. Use the socket
1026 * broadcast or unicast address as appropriate.
1027 */
1028 if (crypto_flags && skeyid > NTP_MAXKEY) {
1029
1030 /*
1031 * More on the autokey dance (AKD). A cookie is
1032 * constructed from public and private values.
1033 * For broadcast packets, the cookie is public
1034 * (zero). For packets that match no
1035 * association, the cookie is hashed from the
1036 * addresses and private value. For server
1037 * packets, the cookie was previously obtained
1038 * from the server. For symmetric modes, the
1039 * cookie was previously constructed using an
1040 * agreement protocol; however, should PKI be
1041 * unavailable, we construct a fake agreement as
1042 * the EXOR of the peer and host cookies.
1043 *
1044 * hismode ephemeral persistent
1045 * =======================================
1046 * active 0 cookie#
1047 * passive 0% cookie#
1048 * client sys cookie 0%
1049 * server 0% sys cookie
1050 * broadcast 0 0
1051 *
1052 * # if unsync, 0
1053 * % can't happen
1054 */
1055 if (has_mac < (int)MAX_MD5_LEN) {
1056 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: drop: MD5 digest too short\n"));
1057 sys_badauth++;
1058 return;
1059 }
1060 if (hismode == MODE_BROADCAST) {
1061
1062 /*
1063 * For broadcaster, use the interface
1064 * broadcast address when available;
1065 * otherwise, use the unicast address
1066 * found when the association was
1067 * mobilized. However, if this is from
1068 * the wildcard interface, game over.
1069 */
1070 if ( crypto_flags
1071 && rbufp->dstadr ==
1072 ANY_INTERFACE_CHOOSE(&rbufp->recv_srcadr)) {
1073 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: drop: BCAST from wildcard\n"));
1074 sys_restricted++;
1075 return; /* no wildcard */
1076 }
1077 pkeyid = 0;
1078 if (!SOCK_UNSPEC(&rbufp->dstadr->bcast))
1079 dstadr_sin =
1080 &rbufp->dstadr->bcast;
1081 } else if (peer == NULL) {
1082 pkeyid = session_key(
1083 &rbufp->recv_srcadr, dstadr_sin, 0,
1084 sys_private, 0);
1085 } else {
1086 pkeyid = peer->pcookie;
1087 }
1088
1089 /*
1090 * The session key includes both the public
1091 * values and cookie. In case of an extension
1092 * field, the cookie used for authentication
1093 * purposes is zero. Note the hash is saved for
1094 * use later in the autokey mambo.
1095 */
1096 if (authlen > (int)LEN_PKT_NOMAC && pkeyid != 0) {
1097 session_key(&rbufp->recv_srcadr,
1098 dstadr_sin, skeyid, 0, 2);
1099 tkeyid = session_key(
1100 &rbufp->recv_srcadr, dstadr_sin,
1101 skeyid, pkeyid, 0);
1102 } else {
1103 tkeyid = session_key(
1104 &rbufp->recv_srcadr, dstadr_sin,
1105 skeyid, pkeyid, 2);
1106 }
1107
1108 }
1109#endif /* AUTOKEY */
1110
1111 /*
1112 * Compute the cryptosum. Note a clogging attack may
1113 * succeed in bloating the key cache. If an autokey,
1114 * purge it immediately, since we won't be needing it
1115 * again. If the packet is authentic, it can mobilize an
1116 * association. Note that there is no key zero.
1117 */
1118 if (!authdecrypt(skeyid, (u_int32 *)pkt, authlen,
1119 has_mac))
1120 is_authentic = AUTH_ERROR;
1121 else
1122 is_authentic = AUTH_OK;
1123#ifdef AUTOKEY
1124 if (crypto_flags && skeyid > NTP_MAXKEY)
1125 authtrust(skeyid, 0);
1126#endif /* AUTOKEY */
1127 DPRINTF(1, ("receive: at %ld %s<-%s mode %d/%s:%s keyid %08x len %d auth %d org %#010x.%08x xmt %#010x.%08x MAC\n",
1128 current_time, stoa(dstadr_sin),
1129 stoa(&rbufp->recv_srcadr), hismode, hm_str, am_str,
1130 skeyid, authlen + has_mac, is_authentic,
1131 ntohl(pkt->org.l_ui), ntohl(pkt->org.l_uf),
1132 ntohl(pkt->xmt.l_ui), ntohl(pkt->xmt.l_uf)));
1133 }
1134
1135
1136 /*
1137 * Bug 3454:
1138 *
1139 * Now come at this from a different perspective:
1140 * - If we expect a MAC and it's not there, we drop it.
1141 * - If we expect one keyID and get another, we drop it.
1142 * - If we have a MAC ahd it hasn't been validated yet, try.
1143 * - if the provided MAC doesn't validate, we drop it.
1144 *
1145 * There might be more to this.
1146 */
1147 if (0 != peer && 0 != peer->keyid) {
1148 /* Should we msyslog() any of these? */
1149
1150 /*
1151 * This should catch:
1152 * - no keyID where one is expected,
1153 * - different keyID than what we expect.
1154 */
1155 if (peer->keyid != skeyid) {
1156 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: drop: Wanted keyID %d, got %d from %s\n",
1157 peer->keyid, skeyid,
1158 stoa(&rbufp->recv_srcadr)));
1159 sys_restricted++;
1160 return; /* drop: access denied */
1161 }
1162
1163 /*
1164 * if has_mac != 0 ...
1165 * - If it has not yet been validated, do so.
1166 * (under what circumstances might that happen?)
1167 * - if missing or bad MAC, log and drop.
1168 */
1169 if (0 != has_mac) {
1170 if (is_authentic == AUTH_UNKNOWN) {
1171 /* How can this happen? */
1172 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: 3454 check: AUTH_UNKNOWN from %s\n",
1173 stoa(&rbufp->recv_srcadr)));
1174 if (!authdecrypt(skeyid, (u_int32 *)pkt, authlen,
1175 has_mac)) {
1176 /* MAC invalid or not found */
1177 is_authentic = AUTH_ERROR;
1178 } else {
1179 is_authentic = AUTH_OK;
1180 }
1181 }
1182 if (is_authentic != AUTH_OK) {
1183 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: drop: missing or bad MAC from %s\n",
1184 stoa(&rbufp->recv_srcadr)));
1185 sys_restricted++;
1186 return; /* drop: access denied */
1187 }
1188 }
1189 }
1190 /**/
1191
1192 /*
1193 ** On-Wire Protocol Layer
1194 **
1195 ** Verify protocol operations consistent with the on-wire protocol.
1196 ** The protocol discards bogus and duplicate packets as well as
1197 ** minimizes disruptions doe to protocol restarts and dropped
1198 ** packets. The operations are controlled by two timestamps:
1199 ** the transmit timestamp saved in the client state variables,
1200 ** and the origin timestamp in the server packet header. The
1201 ** comparison of these two timestamps is called the loopback test.
1202 ** The transmit timestamp functions as a nonce to verify that the
1203 ** response corresponds to the original request. The transmit
1204 ** timestamp also serves to discard replays of the most recent
1205 ** packet. Upon failure of either test, the packet is discarded
1206 ** with no further action.
1207 */
1208
1209 /*
1210 * The association matching rules are implemented by a set of
1211 * routines and an association table. A packet matching an
1212 * association is processed by the peer process for that
1213 * association. If there are no errors, an ephemeral association
1214 * is mobilized: a broadcast packet mobilizes a broadcast client
1215 * aassociation; a manycast server packet mobilizes a manycast
1216 * client association; a symmetric active packet mobilizes a
1217 * symmetric passive association.
1218 */
1219 DPRINTF(1, ("receive: MATCH_ASSOC dispatch: mode %d/%s:%s \n",
1220 hismode, hm_str, am_str));
1221 switch (retcode) {
1222
1223 /*
1224 * This is a client mode packet not matching any association. If
1225 * an ordinary client, simply toss a server mode packet back
1226 * over the fence. If a manycast client, we have to work a
1227 * little harder.
1228 *
1229 * There are cases here where we do not call record_raw_stats().
1230 */
1231 case AM_FXMIT:
1232
1233 /*
1234 * If authentication OK, send a server reply; otherwise,
1235 * send a crypto-NAK.
1236 */
1237 if (!(rbufp->dstadr->flags & INT_MCASTOPEN)) {
1238 /* HMS: would be nice to log FAST_XMIT|BADAUTH|RESTRICTED */
1239 record_raw_stats(&rbufp->recv_srcadr,
1240 &rbufp->dstadr->sin,
1241 &p_org, &p_rec, &p_xmt, &rbufp->recv_time,
1242 PKT_LEAP(pkt->li_vn_mode),
1243 PKT_VERSION(pkt->li_vn_mode),
1244 PKT_MODE(pkt->li_vn_mode),
1245 PKT_TO_STRATUM(pkt->stratum),
1246 pkt->ppoll,
1247 pkt->precision,
1248 FPTOD(NTOHS_FP(pkt->rootdelay)),
1249 FPTOD(NTOHS_FP(pkt->rootdisp)),
1250 pkt->refid,
1251 rbufp->recv_length - MIN_V4_PKT_LEN, (u_char *)&pkt->exten);
1252
1253 if (AUTH(restrict_mask & RES_DONTTRUST,
1254 is_authentic)) {
1255 fast_xmit(rbufp, MODE_SERVER, skeyid,
1256 restrict_mask);
1257 } else if (is_authentic == AUTH_ERROR) {
1258 fast_xmit(rbufp, MODE_SERVER, 0,
1259 restrict_mask);
1260 sys_badauth++;
1261 } else {
1262 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: AM_FXMIT drop: !mcast restricted\n"));
1263 sys_restricted++;
1264 }
1265
1266 return; /* hooray */
1267 }
1268
1269 /*
1270 * This must be manycast. Do not respond if not
1271 * configured as a manycast server.
1272 */
1273 if (!sys_manycastserver) {
1274 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: AM_FXMIT drop: Not manycastserver\n"));
1275 sys_restricted++;
1276 return; /* not enabled */
1277 }
1278
1279#ifdef AUTOKEY
1280 /*
1281 * Do not respond if not the same group.
1282 */
1283 if (group_test(groupname, NULL)) {
1284 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: AM_FXMIT drop: empty groupname\n"));
1285 sys_declined++;
1286 return;
1287 }
1288#endif /* AUTOKEY */
1289
1290 /*
1291 * Do not respond if we are not synchronized or our
1292 * stratum is greater than the manycaster or the
1293 * manycaster has already synchronized to us.
1294 */
1295 if ( sys_leap == LEAP_NOTINSYNC
1296 || sys_stratum >= hisstratum
1297 || (!sys_cohort && sys_stratum == hisstratum + 1)
1298 || rbufp->dstadr->addr_refid == pkt->refid) {
1299 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: AM_FXMIT drop: LEAP_NOTINSYNC || stratum || loop\n"));
1300 sys_declined++;
1301 return; /* no help */
1302 }
1303
1304 /*
1305 * Respond only if authentication succeeds. Don't do a
1306 * crypto-NAK, as that would not be useful.
1307 */
1308 if (AUTH(restrict_mask & RES_DONTTRUST, is_authentic)) {
1309 record_raw_stats(&rbufp->recv_srcadr,
1310 &rbufp->dstadr->sin,
1311 &p_org, &p_rec, &p_xmt, &rbufp->recv_time,
1312 PKT_LEAP(pkt->li_vn_mode),
1313 PKT_VERSION(pkt->li_vn_mode),
1314 PKT_MODE(pkt->li_vn_mode),
1315 PKT_TO_STRATUM(pkt->stratum),
1316 pkt->ppoll,
1317 pkt->precision,
1318 FPTOD(NTOHS_FP(pkt->rootdelay)),
1319 FPTOD(NTOHS_FP(pkt->rootdisp)),
1320 pkt->refid,
1321 rbufp->recv_length - MIN_V4_PKT_LEN, (u_char *)&pkt->exten);
1322
1323 fast_xmit(rbufp, MODE_SERVER, skeyid,
1324 restrict_mask);
1325 }
1326 return; /* hooray */
1327
1328 /*
1329 * This is a server mode packet returned in response to a client
1330 * mode packet sent to a multicast group address (for
1331 * manycastclient) or to a unicast address (for pool). The
1332 * origin timestamp is a good nonce to reliably associate the
1333 * reply with what was sent. If there is no match, that's
1334 * curious and could be an intruder attempting to clog, so we
1335 * just ignore it.
1336 *
1337 * If the packet is authentic and the manycastclient or pool
1338 * association is found, we mobilize a client association and
1339 * copy pertinent variables from the manycastclient or pool
1340 * association to the new client association. If not, just
1341 * ignore the packet.
1342 *
1343 * There is an implosion hazard at the manycast client, since
1344 * the manycast servers send the server packet immediately. If
1345 * the guy is already here, don't fire up a duplicate.
1346 *
1347 * There are cases here where we do not call record_raw_stats().
1348 */
1349 case AM_MANYCAST:
1350
1351#ifdef AUTOKEY
1352 /*
1353 * Do not respond if not the same group.
1354 */
1355 if (group_test(groupname, NULL)) {
1356 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: AM_MANYCAST drop: empty groupname\n"));
1357 sys_declined++;
1358 return;
1359 }
1360#endif /* AUTOKEY */
1361 if ((peer2 = findmanycastpeer(rbufp)) == NULL) {
1362 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: AM_MANYCAST drop: No manycast peer\n"));
1363 sys_restricted++;
1364 return; /* not enabled */
1365 }
1366 if (!AUTH( (!(peer2->cast_flags & MDF_POOL)
1367 && sys_authenticate)
1368 || (restrict_mask & (RES_NOPEER |
1369 RES_DONTTRUST)), is_authentic)
1370 /* MC: RES_NOEPEER? */
1371 ) {
1372 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: AM_MANYCAST drop: bad auth || (NOPEER|DONTTRUST)\n"));
1373 sys_restricted++;
1374 return; /* access denied */
1375 }
1376
1377 /*
1378 * Do not respond if unsynchronized or stratum is below
1379 * the floor or at or above the ceiling.
1380 */
1381 if ( hisleap == LEAP_NOTINSYNC
1382 || hisstratum < sys_floor
1383 || hisstratum >= sys_ceiling) {
1384 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: AM_MANYCAST drop: unsync/stratum\n"));
1385 sys_declined++;
1386 return; /* no help */
1387 }
1388 peer = newpeer(&rbufp->recv_srcadr, NULL, rbufp->dstadr,
1389 r4a.ippeerlimit, MODE_CLIENT, hisversion,
1390 peer2->minpoll, peer2->maxpoll,
1391 FLAG_PREEMPT | (FLAG_IBURST & peer2->flags),
1392 MDF_UCAST | MDF_UCLNT, 0, skeyid, sys_ident);
1393 if (NULL == peer) {
1394 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: AM_MANYCAST drop: duplicate\n"));
1395 sys_declined++;
1396 return; /* ignore duplicate */
1397 }
1398
1399 /*
1400 * After each ephemeral pool association is spun,
1401 * accelerate the next poll for the pool solicitor so
1402 * the pool will fill promptly.
1403 */
1404 if (peer2->cast_flags & MDF_POOL)
1405 peer2->nextdate = current_time + 1;
1406
1407 /*
1408 * Further processing of the solicitation response would
1409 * simply detect its origin timestamp as bogus for the
1410 * brand-new association (it matches the prototype
1411 * association) and tinker with peer->nextdate delaying
1412 * first sync.
1413 */
1414 return; /* solicitation response handled */
1415
1416 /*
1417 * This is the first packet received from a broadcast server. If
1418 * the packet is authentic and we are enabled as broadcast
1419 * client, mobilize a broadcast client association. We don't
1420 * kiss any frogs here.
1421 *
1422 * There are cases here where we do not call record_raw_stats().
1423 */
1424 case AM_NEWBCL:
1425
1426#ifdef AUTOKEY
1427 /*
1428 * Do not respond if not the same group.
1429 */
1430 if (group_test(groupname, sys_ident)) {
1431 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: AM_NEWBCL drop: groupname mismatch\n"));
1432 sys_declined++;
1433 return;
1434 }
1435#endif /* AUTOKEY */
1436 if (sys_bclient == 0) {
1437 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: AM_NEWBCL drop: not a bclient\n"));
1438 sys_restricted++;
1439 return; /* not enabled */
1440 }
1441 if (!AUTH(sys_authenticate | (restrict_mask &
1442 (RES_NOPEER | RES_DONTTRUST)), is_authentic)
1443 /* NEWBCL: RES_NOEPEER? */
1444 ) {
1445 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: AM_NEWBCL drop: AUTH failed\n"));
1446 sys_restricted++;
1447 return; /* access denied */
1448 }
1449
1450 /*
1451 * Do not respond if unsynchronized or stratum is below
1452 * the floor or at or above the ceiling.
1453 */
1454 if ( hisleap == LEAP_NOTINSYNC
1455 || hisstratum < sys_floor
1456 || hisstratum >= sys_ceiling) {
1457 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: AM_NEWBCL drop: Unsync or bad stratum\n"));
1458 sys_declined++;
1459 return; /* no help */
1460 }
1461
1462#ifdef AUTOKEY
1463 /*
1464 * Do not respond if Autokey and the opcode is not a
1465 * CRYPTO_ASSOC response with association ID.
1466 */
1467 if ( crypto_flags && skeyid > NTP_MAXKEY
1468 && (opcode & 0xffff0000) != (CRYPTO_ASSOC | CRYPTO_RESP)) {
1469 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: AM_NEWBCL drop: Autokey but not CRYPTO_ASSOC\n"));
1470 sys_declined++;
1471 return; /* protocol error */
1472 }
1473#endif /* AUTOKEY */
1474
1475 /*
1476 * Broadcasts received via a multicast address may
1477 * arrive after a unicast volley has begun
1478 * with the same remote address. newpeer() will not
1479 * find duplicate associations on other local endpoints
1480 * if a non-NULL endpoint is supplied. multicastclient
1481 * ephemeral associations are unique across all local
1482 * endpoints.
1483 */
1484 if (!(INT_MCASTOPEN & rbufp->dstadr->flags))
1485 match_ep = rbufp->dstadr;
1486 else
1487 match_ep = NULL;
1488
1489 /*
1490 * Determine whether to execute the initial volley.
1491 */
1492 if (sys_bdelay > 0.0) {
1493#ifdef AUTOKEY
1494 /*
1495 * If a two-way exchange is not possible,
1496 * neither is Autokey.
1497 */
1498 if (crypto_flags && skeyid > NTP_MAXKEY) {
1499 sys_restricted++;
1500 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: AM_NEWBCL drop: Autokey but not 2-way\n"));
1501 return; /* no autokey */
1502 }
1503#endif /* AUTOKEY */
1504
1505 /*
1506 * Do not execute the volley. Start out in
1507 * broadcast client mode.
1508 */
1509 peer = newpeer(&rbufp->recv_srcadr, NULL, match_ep,
1510 r4a.ippeerlimit, MODE_BCLIENT, hisversion,
1511 pkt->ppoll, pkt->ppoll,
1512 FLAG_PREEMPT, MDF_BCLNT, 0, skeyid, sys_ident);
1513 if (NULL == peer) {
1514 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: AM_NEWBCL drop: duplicate\n"));
1515 sys_restricted++;
1516 return; /* ignore duplicate */
1517
1518 } else {
1519 peer->delay = sys_bdelay;
1520 peer->bxmt = p_xmt;
1521 }
1522 break;
1523 }
1524
1525 /*
1526 * Execute the initial volley in order to calibrate the
1527 * propagation delay and run the Autokey protocol.
1528 *
1529 * Note that the minpoll is taken from the broadcast
1530 * packet, normally 6 (64 s) and that the poll interval
1531 * is fixed at this value.
1532 */
1533 peer = newpeer(&rbufp->recv_srcadr, NULL, match_ep,
1534 r4a.ippeerlimit, MODE_CLIENT, hisversion,
1535 pkt->ppoll, pkt->ppoll,
1536 FLAG_BC_VOL | FLAG_IBURST | FLAG_PREEMPT, MDF_BCLNT,
1537 0, skeyid, sys_ident);
1538 if (NULL == peer) {
1539 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: AM_NEWBCL drop: empty newpeer() failed\n"));
1540 sys_restricted++;
1541 return; /* ignore duplicate */
1542 }
1543 peer->bxmt = p_xmt;
1544#ifdef AUTOKEY
1545 if (skeyid > NTP_MAXKEY)
1546 crypto_recv(peer, rbufp);
1547#endif /* AUTOKEY */
1548
1549 return; /* hooray */
1550
1551 /*
1552 * This is the first packet received from a potential ephemeral
1553 * symmetric active peer. First, deal with broken Windows clients.
1554 * Then, if NOEPEER is enabled, drop it. If the packet meets our
1555 * authenticty requirements and is the first he sent, mobilize
1556 * a passive association.
1557 * Otherwise, kiss the frog.
1558 *
1559 * There are cases here where we do not call record_raw_stats().
1560 */
1561 case AM_NEWPASS:
1562
1563 DEBUG_REQUIRE(MODE_ACTIVE == hismode);
1564
1565#ifdef AUTOKEY
1566 /*
1567 * Do not respond if not the same group.
1568 */
1569 if (group_test(groupname, sys_ident)) {
1570 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: AM_NEWPASS drop: Autokey group mismatch\n"));
1571 sys_declined++;
1572 return;
1573 }
1574#endif /* AUTOKEY */
1575 if (!AUTH(sys_authenticate | (restrict_mask &
1576 (RES_NOPEER | RES_DONTTRUST)), is_authentic)
1577 ) {
1578 /*
1579 * If authenticated but cannot mobilize an
1580 * association, send a symmetric passive
1581 * response without mobilizing an association.
1582 * This is for drat broken Windows clients. See
1583 * Microsoft KB 875424 for preferred workaround.
1584 */
1585 if (AUTH(restrict_mask & RES_DONTTRUST,
1586 is_authentic)) {
1587 fast_xmit(rbufp, MODE_PASSIVE, skeyid,
1588 restrict_mask);
1589 return; /* hooray */
1590 }
1591 /* HMS: Why is this next set of lines a feature? */
1592 if (is_authentic == AUTH_ERROR) {
1593 fast_xmit(rbufp, MODE_PASSIVE, 0,
1594 restrict_mask);
1595 sys_restricted++;
1596 return;
1597 }
1598
1599 if (restrict_mask & RES_NOEPEER) {
1600 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: AM_NEWPASS drop: NOEPEER\n"));
1601 sys_declined++;
1602 return;
1603 }
1604
1605 /* [Bug 2941]
1606 * If we got here, the packet isn't part of an
1607 * existing association, either isn't correctly
1608 * authenticated or it is but we are refusing
1609 * ephemeral peer requests, and it didn't meet
1610 * either of the previous two special cases so we
1611 * should just drop it on the floor. For example,
1612 * crypto-NAKs (is_authentic == AUTH_CRYPTO)
1613 * will make it this far. This is just
1614 * debug-printed and not logged to avoid log
1615 * flooding.
1616 */
1617 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: at %ld refusing to mobilize passive association"
1618 " with unknown peer %s mode %d/%s:%s keyid %08x len %d auth %d\n",
1619 current_time, stoa(&rbufp->recv_srcadr),
1620 hismode, hm_str, am_str, skeyid,
1621 (authlen + has_mac), is_authentic));
1622 sys_declined++;
1623 return;
1624 }
1625
1626 if (restrict_mask & RES_NOEPEER) {
1627 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: AM_NEWPASS drop: NOEPEER\n"));
1628 sys_declined++;
1629 return;
1630 }
1631
1632 /*
1633 * Do not respond if synchronized and if stratum is
1634 * below the floor or at or above the ceiling. Note,
1635 * this allows an unsynchronized peer to synchronize to
1636 * us. It would be very strange if he did and then was
1637 * nipped, but that could only happen if we were
1638 * operating at the top end of the range. It also means
1639 * we will spin an ephemeral association in response to
1640 * MODE_ACTIVE KoDs, which will time out eventually.
1641 */
1642 if ( hisleap != LEAP_NOTINSYNC
1643 && (hisstratum < sys_floor || hisstratum >= sys_ceiling)) {
1644 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: AM_NEWPASS drop: Autokey group mismatch\n"));
1645 sys_declined++;
1646 return; /* no help */
1647 }
1648
1649 /*
1650 * The message is correctly authenticated and allowed.
1651 * Mobilize a symmetric passive association, if we won't
1652 * exceed the ippeerlimit.
1653 */
1654 if ((peer = newpeer(&rbufp->recv_srcadr, NULL, rbufp->dstadr,
1655 r4a.ippeerlimit, MODE_PASSIVE, hisversion,
1656 pkt->ppoll, NTP_MAXDPOLL, 0, MDF_UCAST, 0,
1657 skeyid, sys_ident)) == NULL) {
1658 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: AM_NEWPASS drop: newpeer() failed\n"));
1659 sys_declined++;
1660 return; /* ignore duplicate */
1661 }
1662 break;
1663
1664
1665 /*
1666 * Process regular packet. Nothing special.
1667 *
1668 * There are cases here where we do not call record_raw_stats().
1669 */
1670 case AM_PROCPKT:
1671
1672#ifdef AUTOKEY
1673 /*
1674 * Do not respond if not the same group.
1675 */
1676 if (group_test(groupname, peer->ident)) {
1677 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: AM_PROCPKT drop: Autokey group mismatch\n"));
1678 sys_declined++;
1679 return;
1680 }
1681#endif /* AUTOKEY */
1682
1683 if (MODE_BROADCAST == hismode) {
1684 int bail = 0;
1685 l_fp tdiff;
1686 u_long deadband;
1687
1688 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: PROCPKT/BROADCAST: prev pkt %ld seconds ago, ppoll: %d, %d secs\n",
1689 (current_time - peer->timelastrec),
1690 peer->ppoll, (1 << peer->ppoll)
1691 ));
1692 /* Things we can check:
1693 *
1694 * Did the poll interval change?
1695 * Is the poll interval in the packet in-range?
1696 * Did this packet arrive too soon?
1697 * Is the timestamp in this packet monotonic
1698 * with respect to the previous packet?
1699 */
1700
1701 /* This is noteworthy, not error-worthy */
1702 if (pkt->ppoll != peer->ppoll) {
1703 msyslog(LOG_INFO, "receive: broadcast poll from %s changed from %u to %u",
1704 stoa(&rbufp->recv_srcadr),
1705 peer->ppoll, pkt->ppoll);
1706 }
1707
1708 /* This is error-worthy */
1709 if ( pkt->ppoll < peer->minpoll
1710 || pkt->ppoll > peer->maxpoll) {
1711 msyslog(LOG_INFO, "receive: broadcast poll of %u from %s is out-of-range (%d to %d)!",
1712 pkt->ppoll, stoa(&rbufp->recv_srcadr),
1713 peer->minpoll, peer->maxpoll);
1714 ++bail;
1715 }
1716
1717 /* too early? worth an error, too!
1718 *
1719 * [Bug 3113] Ensure that at least one poll
1720 * interval has elapsed since the last **clean**
1721 * packet was received. We limit the check to
1722 * **clean** packets to prevent replayed packets
1723 * and incorrectly authenticated packets, which
1724 * we'll discard, from being used to create a
1725 * denial of service condition.
1726 */
1727 deadband = (1u << pkt->ppoll);
1728 if (FLAG_BC_VOL & peer->flags)
1729 deadband -= 3; /* allow greater fuzz after volley */
1730 if ((current_time - peer->timereceived) < deadband) {
1731 msyslog(LOG_INFO, "receive: broadcast packet from %s arrived after %lu, not %lu seconds!",
1732 stoa(&rbufp->recv_srcadr),
1733 (current_time - peer->timereceived),
1734 deadband);
1735 ++bail;
1736 }
1737
1738 /* Alert if time from the server is non-monotonic.
1739 *
1740 * [Bug 3114] is about Broadcast mode replay DoS.
1741 *
1742 * Broadcast mode *assumes* a trusted network.
1743 * Even so, it's nice to be robust in the face
1744 * of attacks.
1745 *
1746 * If we get an authenticated broadcast packet
1747 * with an "earlier" timestamp, it means one of
1748 * two things:
1749 *
1750 * - the broadcast server had a backward step.
1751 *
1752 * - somebody is trying a replay attack.
1753 *
1754 * deadband: By default, we assume the broadcast
1755 * network is trustable, so we take our accepted
1756 * broadcast packets as we receive them. But
1757 * some folks might want to take additional poll
1758 * delays before believing a backward step.
1759 */
1760 if (sys_bcpollbstep) {
1761 /* pkt->ppoll or peer->ppoll ? */
1762 deadband = (1u << pkt->ppoll)
1763 * sys_bcpollbstep + 2;
1764 } else {
1765 deadband = 0;
1766 }
1767
1768 if (L_ISZERO(&peer->bxmt)) {
1769 tdiff.l_ui = tdiff.l_uf = 0;
1770 } else {
1771 tdiff = p_xmt;
1772 L_SUB(&tdiff, &peer->bxmt);
1773 }
1774 if ( tdiff.l_i < 0
1775 && (current_time - peer->timereceived) < deadband)
1776 {
1777 msyslog(LOG_INFO, "receive: broadcast packet from %s contains non-monotonic timestamp: %#010x.%08x -> %#010x.%08x",
1778 stoa(&rbufp->recv_srcadr),
1779 peer->bxmt.l_ui, peer->bxmt.l_uf,
1780 p_xmt.l_ui, p_xmt.l_uf
1781 );
1782 ++bail;
1783 }
1784
1785 if (bail) {
1786 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: AM_PROCPKT drop: bail\n"));
1787 peer->timelastrec = current_time;
1788 sys_declined++;
1789 return;
1790 }
1791 }
1792
1793 break;
1794
1795 /*
1796 * A passive packet matches a passive association. This is
1797 * usually the result of reconfiguring a client on the fly. As
1798 * this association might be legitimate and this packet an
1799 * attempt to deny service, just ignore it.
1800 */
1801 case AM_ERR:
1802 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: AM_ERR drop.\n"));
1803 sys_declined++;
1804 return;
1805
1806 /*
1807 * For everything else there is the bit bucket.
1808 */
1809 default:
1810 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: default drop.\n"));
1811 sys_declined++;
1812 return;
1813 }
1814
1815#ifdef AUTOKEY
1816 /*
1817 * If the association is configured for Autokey, the packet must
1818 * have a public key ID; if not, the packet must have a
1819 * symmetric key ID.
1820 */
1821 if ( is_authentic != AUTH_CRYPTO
1822 && ( ((peer->flags & FLAG_SKEY) && skeyid <= NTP_MAXKEY)
1823 || (!(peer->flags & FLAG_SKEY) && skeyid > NTP_MAXKEY))) {
1824 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: drop: Autokey but wrong/bad auth\n"));
1825 sys_badauth++;
1826 return;
1827 }
1828#endif /* AUTOKEY */
1829
1830 peer->received++;
1831 peer->flash &= ~PKT_TEST_MASK;
1832 if (peer->flags & FLAG_XBOGUS) {
1833 peer->flags &= ~FLAG_XBOGUS;
1834 peer->flash |= TEST3;
1835 }
1836
1837 /*
1838 * Next comes a rigorous schedule of timestamp checking. If the
1839 * transmit timestamp is zero, the server has not initialized in
1840 * interleaved modes or is horribly broken.
1841 *
1842 * A KoD packet we pay attention to cannot have a 0 transmit
1843 * timestamp.
1844 */
1845
1846 kissCode = kiss_code_check(hisleap, hisstratum, hismode, pkt->refid);
1847
1848 if (L_ISZERO(&p_xmt)) {
1849 peer->flash |= TEST3; /* unsynch */
1850 if (kissCode != NOKISS) { /* KoD packet */
1851 peer->bogusorg++; /* for TEST2 or TEST3 */
1852 msyslog(LOG_INFO,
1853 "receive: Unexpected zero transmit timestamp in KoD from %s",
1854 ntoa(&peer->srcadr));
1855 return;
1856 }
1857
1858 /*
1859 * If the transmit timestamp duplicates our previous one, the
1860 * packet is a replay. This prevents the bad guys from replaying
1861 * the most recent packet, authenticated or not.
1862 */
1863 } else if (L_ISEQU(&peer->xmt, &p_xmt)) {
1864 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: drop: Duplicate xmit\n"));
1865 peer->flash |= TEST1; /* duplicate */
1866 peer->oldpkt++;
1867 return;
1868
1869 /*
1870 * If this is a broadcast mode packet, make sure hisstratum
1871 * is appropriate. Don't do anything else here - we wait to
1872 * see if this is an interleave broadcast packet until after
1873 * we've validated the MAC that SHOULD be provided.
1874 *
1875 * hisstratum cannot be 0 - see assertion above.
1876 * If hisstratum is 15, then we'll advertise as UNSPEC but
1877 * at least we'll be able to sync with the broadcast server.
1878 */
1879 } else if (hismode == MODE_BROADCAST) {
1880 /* 0 is unexpected too, and impossible */
1881 if (STRATUM_UNSPEC <= hisstratum) {
1882 /* Is this a ++sys_declined or ??? */
1883 msyslog(LOG_INFO,
1884 "receive: Unexpected stratum (%d) in broadcast from %s",
1885 hisstratum, ntoa(&peer->srcadr));
1886 return;
1887 }
1888
1889 /*
1890 * Basic KoD validation checking:
1891 *
1892 * KoD packets are a mixed-blessing. Forged KoD packets
1893 * are DoS attacks. There are rare situations where we might
1894 * get a valid KoD response, though. Since KoD packets are
1895 * a special case that complicate the checks we do next, we
1896 * handle the basic KoD checks here.
1897 *
1898 * Note that we expect the incoming KoD packet to have its
1899 * (nonzero) org, rec, and xmt timestamps set to the xmt timestamp
1900 * that we have previously sent out. Watch interleave mode.
1901 */
1902 } else if (kissCode != NOKISS) {
1903 DEBUG_INSIST(!L_ISZERO(&p_xmt));
1904 if ( L_ISZERO(&p_org) /* We checked p_xmt above */
1905 || L_ISZERO(&p_rec)) {
1906 peer->bogusorg++;
1907 msyslog(LOG_INFO,
1908 "receive: KoD packet from %s has a zero org or rec timestamp. Ignoring.",
1909 ntoa(&peer->srcadr));
1910 return;
1911 }
1912
1913 if ( !L_ISEQU(&p_xmt, &p_org)
1914 || !L_ISEQU(&p_xmt, &p_rec)) {
1915 peer->bogusorg++;
1916 msyslog(LOG_INFO,
1917 "receive: KoD packet from %s has inconsistent xmt/org/rec timestamps. Ignoring.",
1918 ntoa(&peer->srcadr));
1919 return;
1920 }
1921
1922 /* Be conservative */
1923 if (peer->flip == 0 && !L_ISEQU(&p_org, &peer->aorg)) {
1924 peer->bogusorg++;
1925 msyslog(LOG_INFO,
1926 "receive: flip 0 KoD origin timestamp %#010x.%08x from %s does not match %#010x.%08x - ignoring.",
1927 p_org.l_ui, p_org.l_uf,
1928 ntoa(&peer->srcadr),
1929 peer->aorg.l_ui, peer->aorg.l_uf);
1930 return;
1931 } else if (peer->flip == 1 && !L_ISEQU(&p_org, &peer->borg)) {
1932 peer->bogusorg++;
1933 msyslog(LOG_INFO,
1934 "receive: flip 1 KoD origin timestamp %#010x.%08x from %s does not match interleave %#010x.%08x - ignoring.",
1935 p_org.l_ui, p_org.l_uf,
1936 ntoa(&peer->srcadr),
1937 peer->borg.l_ui, peer->borg.l_uf);
1938 return;
1939 }
1940
1941 /*
1942 * Basic mode checks:
1943 *
1944 * If there is no origin timestamp, it's either an initial packet
1945 * or we've already received a response to our query. Of course,
1946 * should 'aorg' be all-zero because this really was the original
1947 * transmit timestamp, we'll ignore this reply. There is a window
1948 * of one nanosecond once every 136 years' time where this is
1949 * possible. We currently ignore this situation, as a completely
1950 * zero timestamp is (quietly?) disallowed.
1951 *
1952 * Otherwise, check for bogus packet in basic mode.
1953 * If it is bogus, switch to interleaved mode and resynchronize,
1954 * but only after confirming the packet is not bogus in
1955 * symmetric interleaved mode.
1956 *
1957 * This could also mean somebody is forging packets claiming to
1958 * be from us, attempting to cause our server to KoD us.
1959 *
1960 * We have earlier asserted that hisstratum cannot be 0.
1961 * If hisstratum is STRATUM_UNSPEC, it means he's not sync'd.
1962 */
1963 } else if (peer->flip == 0) {
1964 if (0) {
1965 } else if (L_ISZERO(&p_org)) {
1966 const char *action;
1967
1968#ifdef BUG3361
1969 msyslog(LOG_INFO,
1970 "receive: BUG 3361: Clearing peer->aorg ");
1971 L_CLR(&peer->aorg);
1972#endif
1973 /**/
1974 switch (hismode) {
1975 /* We allow 0org for: */
1976 case UCHAR_MAX:
1977 action = "Allow";
1978 break;
1979 /* We disallow 0org for: */
1980 case MODE_UNSPEC:
1981 case MODE_ACTIVE:
1982 case MODE_PASSIVE:
1983 case MODE_CLIENT:
1984 case MODE_SERVER:
1985 case MODE_BROADCAST:
1986 action = "Drop";
1987 peer->bogusorg++;
1988 peer->flash |= TEST2; /* bogus */
1989 break;
1990 default:
1991 action = ""; /* for cranky compilers / MSVC */
1992 INSIST(!"receive(): impossible hismode");
1993 break;
1994 }
1995 /**/
1996 msyslog(LOG_INFO,
1997 "receive: %s 0 origin timestamp from %s@%s xmt %#010x.%08x",
1998 action, hm_str, ntoa(&peer->srcadr),
1999 ntohl(pkt->xmt.l_ui), ntohl(pkt->xmt.l_uf));
2000 } else if (!L_ISEQU(&p_org, &peer->aorg)) {
2001 /* are there cases here where we should bail? */
2002 /* Should we set TEST2 if we decide to try xleave? */
2003 peer->bogusorg++;
2004 peer->flash |= TEST2; /* bogus */
2005 msyslog(LOG_INFO,
2006 "receive: Unexpected origin timestamp %#010x.%08x does not match aorg %#010x.%08x from %s@%s xmt %#010x.%08x",
2007 ntohl(pkt->org.l_ui), ntohl(pkt->org.l_uf),
2008 peer->aorg.l_ui, peer->aorg.l_uf,
2009 hm_str, ntoa(&peer->srcadr),
2010 ntohl(pkt->xmt.l_ui), ntohl(pkt->xmt.l_uf));
2011 if ( !L_ISZERO(&peer->dst)
2012 && L_ISEQU(&p_org, &peer->dst)) {
2013 /* Might be the start of an interleave */
2014 if (dynamic_interleave) {
2015 peer->flip = 1;
2016 report_event(PEVNT_XLEAVE, peer, NULL);
2017 } else {
2018 msyslog(LOG_INFO,
2019 "receive: Dynamic interleave from %s@%s denied",
2020 hm_str, ntoa(&peer->srcadr));
2021 }
2022 }
2023 } else {
2024 L_CLR(&peer->aorg);
2025 }
2026
2027 /*
2028 * Check for valid nonzero timestamp fields.
2029 */
2030 } else if ( L_ISZERO(&p_org)
2031 || L_ISZERO(&p_rec)
2032 || L_ISZERO(&peer->dst)) {
2033 peer->flash |= TEST3; /* unsynch */
2034
2035 /*
2036 * Check for bogus packet in interleaved symmetric mode. This
2037 * can happen if a packet is lost, duplicated or crossed. If
2038 * found, flip and resynchronize.
2039 */
2040 } else if ( !L_ISZERO(&peer->dst)
2041 && !L_ISEQU(&p_org, &peer->dst)) {
2042 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: drop: Bogus packet in interleaved symmetric mode\n"));
2043 peer->bogusorg++;
2044 peer->flags |= FLAG_XBOGUS;
2045 peer->flash |= TEST2; /* bogus */
2046#ifdef BUG3453
2047 return; /* Bogus packet, we are done */
2048#endif
2049 }
2050
2051 /**/
2052
2053 /*
2054 * If this is a crypto_NAK, the server cannot authenticate a
2055 * client packet. The server might have just changed keys. Clear
2056 * the association and restart the protocol.
2057 */
2058 if (crypto_nak_test == VALIDNAK) {
2059 report_event(PEVNT_AUTH, peer, "crypto_NAK");
2060 peer->flash |= TEST5; /* bad auth */
2061 peer->badauth++;
2062 if (peer->flags & FLAG_PREEMPT) {
2063 if (unpeer_crypto_nak_early) {
2064 unpeer(peer);
2065 }
2066 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: drop: PREEMPT crypto_NAK\n"));
2067 return;
2068 }
2069#ifdef AUTOKEY
2070 if (peer->crypto) {
2071 peer_clear(peer, "AUTH");
2072 }
2073#endif /* AUTOKEY */
2074 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: drop: crypto_NAK\n"));
2075 return;
2076
2077 /*
2078 * If the digest fails or it's missing for authenticated
2079 * associations, the client cannot authenticate a server
2080 * reply to a client packet previously sent. The loopback check
2081 * is designed to avoid a bait-and-switch attack, which was
2082 * possible in past versions. If symmetric modes, return a
2083 * crypto-NAK. The peer should restart the protocol.
2084 */
2085 } else if (!AUTH(peer->keyid || has_mac ||
2086 (restrict_mask & RES_DONTTRUST), is_authentic)) {
2087
2088 if (peer->flash & PKT_TEST_MASK) {
2089 msyslog(LOG_INFO,
2090 "receive: Bad auth in packet with bad timestamps from %s denied - spoof?",
2091 ntoa(&peer->srcadr));
2092 return;
2093 }
2094
2095 report_event(PEVNT_AUTH, peer, "digest");
2096 peer->flash |= TEST5; /* bad auth */
2097 peer->badauth++;
2098 if ( has_mac
2099 && ( hismode == MODE_ACTIVE
2100 || hismode == MODE_PASSIVE))
2101 fast_xmit(rbufp, MODE_ACTIVE, 0, restrict_mask);
2102 if (peer->flags & FLAG_PREEMPT) {
2103 if (unpeer_digest_early) {
2104 unpeer(peer);
2105 }
2106 }
2107#ifdef AUTOKEY
2108 else if (peer_clear_digest_early && peer->crypto) {
2109 peer_clear(peer, "AUTH");
2110 }
2111#endif /* AUTOKEY */
2112 DPRINTF(2, ("receive: drop: Bad or missing AUTH\n"));
2113 return;
2114 }
2115
2116 /*
2117 * For broadcast packets:
2118 *
2119 * HMS: This next line never made much sense to me, even
2120 * when it was up higher:
2121 * If an initial volley, bail out now and let the
2122 * client do its stuff.
2123 *
2124 * If the packet has not failed authentication, then
2125 * - if the origin timestamp is nonzero this is an
2126 * interleaved broadcast, so restart the protocol.
2127 * - else, this is not an interleaved broadcast packet.
2128 */
2129 if (hismode == MODE_BROADCAST) {
2130 if ( is_authentic == AUTH_OK
2131 || is_authentic == AUTH_NONE) {
2132 if (!L_ISZERO(&p_org)) {
2133 if (!(peer->flags & FLAG_XB)) {
2134 msyslog(LOG_INFO,
2135 "receive: Broadcast server at %s is in interleave mode",
2136 ntoa(&peer->srcadr));
2137 peer->flags |= FLAG_XB;
2138 peer->aorg = p_xmt;
2139 peer->borg = rbufp->recv_time;
2140 report_event(PEVNT_XLEAVE, peer, NULL);
2141 return;
2142 }
2143 } else if (peer->flags & FLAG_XB) {
2144 msyslog(LOG_INFO,
2145 "receive: Broadcast server at %s is no longer in interleave mode",
2146 ntoa(&peer->srcadr));
2147 peer->flags &= ~FLAG_XB;
2148 }
2149 } else {
2150 msyslog(LOG_INFO,
2151 "receive: Bad broadcast auth (%d) from %s",
2152 is_authentic, ntoa(&peer->srcadr));
2153 }
2154
2155 /*
2156 * Now that we know the packet is correctly authenticated,
2157 * update peer->bxmt.
2158 */
2159 peer->bxmt = p_xmt;
2160 }
2161
2162
2163 /*
2164 ** Update the state variables.
2165 */
2166 if (peer->flip == 0) {
2167 if (hismode != MODE_BROADCAST)
2168 peer->rec = p_xmt;
2169 peer->dst = rbufp->recv_time;
2170 }
2171 peer->xmt = p_xmt;
2172
2173 /*
2174 * Set the peer ppoll to the maximum of the packet ppoll and the
2175 * peer minpoll. If a kiss-o'-death, set the peer minpoll to
2176 * this maximum and advance the headway to give the sender some
2177 * headroom. Very intricate.
2178 */
2179
2180 /*
2181 * Check for any kiss codes. Note this is only used when a server
2182 * responds to a packet request.
2183 */
2184
2185 /*
2186 * Check to see if this is a RATE Kiss Code
2187 * Currently this kiss code will accept whatever poll
2188 * rate that the server sends
2189 */
2190 peer->ppoll = max(peer->minpoll, pkt->ppoll);
2191 if (kissCode == RATEKISS) {
2192 peer->selbroken++; /* Increment the KoD count */
2193 report_event(PEVNT_RATE, peer, NULL);
2194 if (pkt->ppoll > peer->minpoll)
2195 peer->minpoll = peer->ppoll;
2196 peer->burst = peer->retry = 0;
2197 peer->throttle = (NTP_SHIFT + 1) * (1 << peer->minpoll);
2198 poll_update(peer, pkt->ppoll);
2199 return; /* kiss-o'-death */
2200 }
2201 if (kissCode != NOKISS) {
2202 peer->selbroken++; /* Increment the KoD count */
2203 return; /* Drop any other kiss code packets */
2204 }
2205
2206
2207 /*
2208 * XXX
2209 */
2210
2211
2212 /*
2213 * If:
2214 * - this is a *cast (uni-, broad-, or m-) server packet
2215 * - and it's symmetric-key authenticated
2216 * then see if the sender's IP is trusted for this keyid.
2217 * If it is, great - nothing special to do here.
2218 * Otherwise, we should report and bail.
2219 *
2220 * Autokey-authenticated packets are accepted.
2221 */
2222
2223 switch (hismode) {
2224 case MODE_SERVER: /* server mode */
2225 case MODE_BROADCAST: /* broadcast mode */
2226 case MODE_ACTIVE: /* symmetric active mode */
2227 case MODE_PASSIVE: /* symmetric passive mode */
2228 if ( is_authentic == AUTH_OK
2229 && skeyid
2230 && skeyid <= NTP_MAXKEY
2231 && !authistrustedip(skeyid, &peer->srcadr)) {
2232 report_event(PEVNT_AUTH, peer, "authIP");
2233 peer->badauth++;
2234 return;
2235 }
2236 break;
2237
2238 case MODE_CLIENT: /* client mode */
2239#if 0 /* At this point, MODE_CONTROL is overloaded by MODE_BCLIENT */
2240 case MODE_CONTROL: /* control mode */
2241#endif
2242 case MODE_PRIVATE: /* private mode */
2243 case MODE_BCLIENT: /* broadcast client mode */
2244 break;
2245
2246 case MODE_UNSPEC: /* unspecified (old version) */
2247 default:
2248 msyslog(LOG_INFO,
2249 "receive: Unexpected mode (%d) in packet from %s",
2250 hismode, ntoa(&peer->srcadr));
2251 break;
2252 }
2253
2254
2255 /*
2256 * That was hard and I am sweaty, but the packet is squeaky
2257 * clean. Get on with real work.
2258 */
2259 peer->timereceived = current_time;
2260 peer->timelastrec = current_time;
2261 if (is_authentic == AUTH_OK)
2262 peer->flags |= FLAG_AUTHENTIC;
2263 else
2264 peer->flags &= ~FLAG_AUTHENTIC;
2265
2266#ifdef AUTOKEY
2267 /*
2268 * More autokey dance. The rules of the cha-cha are as follows:
2269 *
2270 * 1. If there is no key or the key is not auto, do nothing.
2271 *
2272 * 2. If this packet is in response to the one just previously
2273 * sent or from a broadcast server, do the extension fields.
2274 * Otherwise, assume bogosity and bail out.
2275 *
2276 * 3. If an extension field contains a verified signature, it is
2277 * self-authenticated and we sit the dance.
2278 *
2279 * 4. If this is a server reply, check only to see that the
2280 * transmitted key ID matches the received key ID.
2281 *
2282 * 5. Check to see that one or more hashes of the current key ID
2283 * matches the previous key ID or ultimate original key ID
2284 * obtained from the broadcaster or symmetric peer. If no
2285 * match, sit the dance and call for new autokey values.
2286 *
2287 * In case of crypto error, fire the orchestra, stop dancing and
2288 * restart the protocol.
2289 */
2290 if (peer->flags & FLAG_SKEY) {
2291 /*
2292 * Decrement remaining autokey hashes. This isn't
2293 * perfect if a packet is lost, but results in no harm.
2294 */
2295 ap = (struct autokey *)peer->recval.ptr;
2296 if (ap != NULL) {
2297 if (ap->seq > 0)
2298 ap->seq--;
2299 }
2300 peer->flash |= TEST8;
2301 rval = crypto_recv(peer, rbufp);
2302 if (rval == XEVNT_OK) {
2303 peer->unreach = 0;
2304 } else {
2305 if (rval == XEVNT_ERR) {
2306 report_event(PEVNT_RESTART, peer,
2307 "crypto error");
2308 peer_clear(peer, "CRYP");
2309 peer->flash |= TEST9; /* bad crypt */
2310 if (peer->flags & FLAG_PREEMPT) {
2311 if (unpeer_crypto_early) {
2312 unpeer(peer);
2313 }
2314 }
2315 }
2316 return;
2317 }
2318
2319 /*
2320 * If server mode, verify the receive key ID matches
2321 * the transmit key ID.
2322 */
2323 if (hismode == MODE_SERVER) {
2324 if (skeyid == peer->keyid)
2325 peer->flash &= ~TEST8;
2326
2327 /*
2328 * If an extension field is present, verify only that it
2329 * has been correctly signed. We don't need a sequence
2330 * check here, but the sequence continues.
2331 */
2332 } else if (!(peer->flash & TEST8)) {
2333 peer->pkeyid = skeyid;
2334
2335 /*
2336 * Now the fun part. Here, skeyid is the current ID in
2337 * the packet, pkeyid is the ID in the last packet and
2338 * tkeyid is the hash of skeyid. If the autokey values
2339 * have not been received, this is an automatic error.
2340 * If so, check that the tkeyid matches pkeyid. If not,
2341 * hash tkeyid and try again. If the number of hashes
2342 * exceeds the number remaining in the sequence, declare
2343 * a successful failure and refresh the autokey values.
2344 */
2345 } else if (ap != NULL) {
2346 int i;
2347
2348 for (i = 0; ; i++) {
2349 if ( tkeyid == peer->pkeyid
2350 || tkeyid == ap->key) {
2351 peer->flash &= ~TEST8;
2352 peer->pkeyid = skeyid;
2353 ap->seq -= i;
2354 break;
2355 }
2356 if (i > ap->seq) {
2357 peer->crypto &=
2358 ~CRYPTO_FLAG_AUTO;
2359 break;
2360 }
2361 tkeyid = session_key(
2362 &rbufp->recv_srcadr, dstadr_sin,
2363 tkeyid, pkeyid, 0);
2364 }
2365 if (peer->flash & TEST8)
2366 report_event(PEVNT_AUTH, peer, "keylist");
2367 }
2368 if (!(peer->crypto & CRYPTO_FLAG_PROV)) /* test 9 */
2369 peer->flash |= TEST8; /* bad autokey */
2370
2371 /*
2372 * The maximum lifetime of the protocol is about one
2373 * week before restarting the Autokey protocol to
2374 * refresh certificates and leapseconds values.
2375 */
2376 if (current_time > peer->refresh) {
2377 report_event(PEVNT_RESTART, peer,
2378 "crypto refresh");
2379 peer_clear(peer, "TIME");
2380 return;
2381 }
2382 }
2383#endif /* AUTOKEY */
2384
2385 /*
2386 * The dance is complete and the flash bits have been lit. Toss
2387 * the packet over the fence for processing, which may light up
2388 * more flashers.
2389 */
2390 process_packet(peer, pkt, rbufp->recv_length);
2391
2392 /*
2393 * In interleaved mode update the state variables. Also adjust the
2394 * transmit phase to avoid crossover.
2395 */
2396 if (peer->flip != 0) {
2397 peer->rec = p_rec;
2398 peer->dst = rbufp->recv_time;
2399 if (peer->nextdate - current_time < (1U << min(peer->ppoll,
2400 peer->hpoll)) / 2)
2401 peer->nextdate++;
2402 else
2403 peer->nextdate--;
2404 }
2405}
2406
2407
2408/*
2409 * process_packet - Packet Procedure, a la Section 3.4.4 of RFC-1305
2410 * Or almost, at least. If we're in here we have a reasonable
2411 * expectation that we will be having a long term
2412 * relationship with this host.
2413 */
2414void
2415process_packet(
2416 register struct peer *peer,
2417 register struct pkt *pkt,
2418 u_int len
2419 )
2420{
2421 double t34, t21;
2422 double p_offset, p_del, p_disp;
2423 l_fp p_rec, p_xmt, p_org, p_reftime, ci;
2424 u_char pmode, pleap, pversion, pstratum;
2425 char statstr[NTP_MAXSTRLEN];
2426#ifdef ASSYM
2427 int itemp;
2428 double etemp, ftemp, td;
2429#endif /* ASSYM */
2430
2431#if 0
2432 sys_processed++;
2433 peer->processed++;
2434#endif
2435 p_del = FPTOD(NTOHS_FP(pkt->rootdelay));
2436 p_offset = 0;
2437 p_disp = FPTOD(NTOHS_FP(pkt->rootdisp));
2438 NTOHL_FP(&pkt->reftime, &p_reftime);
2439 NTOHL_FP(&pkt->org, &p_org);
2440 NTOHL_FP(&pkt->rec, &p_rec);
2441 NTOHL_FP(&pkt->xmt, &p_xmt);
2442 pmode = PKT_MODE(pkt->li_vn_mode);
2443 pleap = PKT_LEAP(pkt->li_vn_mode);
2444 pversion = PKT_VERSION(pkt->li_vn_mode);
2445 pstratum = PKT_TO_STRATUM(pkt->stratum);
2446
2447 /**/
2448
2449 /**/
2450
2451 /*
2452 * Verify the server is synchronized; that is, the leap bits,
2453 * stratum and root distance are valid.
2454 */
2455 if ( pleap == LEAP_NOTINSYNC /* test 6 */
2456 || pstratum < sys_floor || pstratum >= sys_ceiling)
2457 peer->flash |= TEST6; /* bad synch or strat */
2458 if (p_del / 2 + p_disp >= MAXDISPERSE) /* test 7 */
2459 peer->flash |= TEST7; /* bad header */
2460
2461 /*
2462 * If any tests fail at this point, the packet is discarded.
2463 * Note that some flashers may have already been set in the
2464 * receive() routine.
2465 */
2466 if (peer->flash & PKT_TEST_MASK) {
2467 peer->seldisptoolarge++;
2468 DPRINTF(1, ("packet: flash header %04x\n",
2469 peer->flash));
2470 poll_update(peer, peer->hpoll); /* ppoll updated? */
2471 return;
2472 }
2473
2474 /**/
2475
2476#if 1
2477 sys_processed++;
2478 peer->processed++;
2479#endif
2480
2481 /*
2482 * Capture the header values in the client/peer association..
2483 */
2484 record_raw_stats(&peer->srcadr,
2485 peer->dstadr ? &peer->dstadr->sin : NULL,
2486 &p_org, &p_rec, &p_xmt, &peer->dst,
2487 pleap, pversion, pmode, pstratum, pkt->ppoll, pkt->precision,
2488 p_del, p_disp, pkt->refid,
2489 len - MIN_V4_PKT_LEN, (u_char *)&pkt->exten);
2490 peer->leap = pleap;
2491 peer->stratum = min(pstratum, STRATUM_UNSPEC);
2492 peer->pmode = pmode;
2493 peer->precision = pkt->precision;
2494 peer->rootdelay = p_del;
2495 peer->rootdisp = p_disp;
2496 peer->refid = pkt->refid; /* network byte order */
2497 peer->reftime = p_reftime;
2498
2499 /*
2500 * First, if either burst mode is armed, enable the burst.
2501 * Compute the headway for the next packet and delay if
2502 * necessary to avoid exceeding the threshold.
2503 */
2504 if (peer->retry > 0) {
2505 peer->retry = 0;
2506 if (peer->reach)
2507 peer->burst = min(1 << (peer->hpoll -
2508 peer->minpoll), NTP_SHIFT) - 1;
2509 else
2510 peer->burst = NTP_IBURST - 1;
2511 if (peer->burst > 0)
2512 peer->nextdate = current_time;
2513 }
2514 poll_update(peer, peer->hpoll);
2515
2516 /**/
2517
2518 /*
2519 * If the peer was previously unreachable, raise a trap. In any
2520 * case, mark it reachable.
2521 */
2522 if (!peer->reach) {
2523 report_event(PEVNT_REACH, peer, NULL);
2524 peer->timereachable = current_time;
2525 }
2526 peer->reach |= 1;
2527
2528 /*
2529 * For a client/server association, calculate the clock offset,
2530 * roundtrip delay and dispersion. The equations are reordered
2531 * from the spec for more efficient use of temporaries. For a
2532 * broadcast association, offset the last measurement by the
2533 * computed delay during the client/server volley. Note the
2534 * computation of dispersion includes the system precision plus
2535 * that due to the frequency error since the origin time.
2536 *
2537 * It is very important to respect the hazards of overflow. The
2538 * only permitted operation on raw timestamps is subtraction,
2539 * where the result is a signed quantity spanning from 68 years
2540 * in the past to 68 years in the future. To avoid loss of
2541 * precision, these calculations are done using 64-bit integer
2542 * arithmetic. However, the offset and delay calculations are
2543 * sums and differences of these first-order differences, which
2544 * if done using 64-bit integer arithmetic, would be valid over
2545 * only half that span. Since the typical first-order
2546 * differences are usually very small, they are converted to 64-
2547 * bit doubles and all remaining calculations done in floating-
